Computes the linear optimal LQ full-state gain K for the linear dynamical system P: \dot{x}=A x+B u \text{ in continuous time or }x^+=A x+B u \text{ in discrete time.} And instantaneous cost function in l2-norm: \left[\begin{array}{ll}x'&u'\end{array}\right] BigQ \left[\begin{array}{l}x\\u\end{array}\right]\text{ where }BigQ=\left[\begin{array}{ll}Q&S'\\S&R\end{array}\right]

para.note: In this case the P.C and P.D componants of the system are ignored.

An equivalent form for the equation is (\overline{A}' \text{X}^{-1}+B R^{-1} B') \overline{A}+\overline{Q}-\text{X}=0 with \overline{A}=A-B R^{-1} S'\text{ and }\overline{Q}=Q-S R^{-1} S'

refsect2.para: The gain K is such that A + B.K is stable.

The resolution of the Riccati equation is obtained by schur factorization of the 3-blocks matrix pencils associated with these Riccati equations:
For a continuous plant s\left[\begin{array}{lll}I&0&0\\0&I&0\\0&0&0\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{lll}A&0&B\\-Q&-A'&-S'\\S&-B'&R\end{array}\right]
For a discrete time plant z\left[\begin{array}{lll}I&0&0\\0&A'&0\\0&-B'&0\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{lll}A&0& B\\-Q&I&-S'\\S&0& R\end{array}\right]

warning.para: It is assumed that matrix R or D'D is non singular.

note.para: Remark: If the full state of the system is not available, an estimator can be built using the lqe or the lqg function.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.para:
Assume the dynamical system formed by two masses connected by a spring and a damper:
A force u=\bar{u}+e (where e is a noise) is applied to the big one. Here it is assumed that the deviations from equilibrium positions of the mass dy1 and dy2 positions has well as their derivatives are measured.

A state space representation of this system is:
\dot{x}=\left[\begin{array}{llll}0&1&0&0\\ -k/M&-b/M&k/M&b/M\\ 0&0&0&1\\ k/m&b/m&-k/m&-b/m \end{array}\right] x +\left[\begin{array}{l}0\\ 1/M\\ 0\\ 0 \end{array}\right] u \text{Where }x=\left[\begin{array}{l}dy_1\\ \dot{dy_1}\\ dy_2\\ \dot{dy_2}\end{array}\right]
The LQ cost is defined by \int_0^\infty\left[\begin{array}{ll}x'&u'\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ll}Q_{xx}&0\\0&R_{uu}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x\\u\end{array}\right] dt
The following instructions may be used to compute a LQ compensator of this dynamical system.
